newsitem.title: USA: U.S. stocks seen lower, Motorola warns on Q3.
newsitem.headline: U.S. stocks seen lower, Motorola warns on Q3.

text.p: Wall Street stocks are expected to open lower on Wednesday, jolted by a warning from semiconductor and telecommunications equipment giant Motorola Inc that its third quarter earnings were likely to disappoint.

Analysts said the comment was likely to post an early challenge to stocks, recalling that in July, Motorola's surprisingly weak earnings helped trigger a sharp sell-off that hit technology stocks particularly hard.
However, analysts stopped short of calling for a re-enactment of the widespread selling pressure based on this quarter's comments.

"It was Motorola that helped shake up the market in July but since then it appears that the market has already digested most of the problems," said Larry Wachtel, market analyst at Prudential Securities.

Helping to offset the warning are several factors, analysts said, including Motorola's underperformance during the broader market's late summer recovery, an indication that investors remained aware of the company's problems.
Continued strength in the dollar is also expected to offer some support, said analysts.

"Are we in for a major decline? I don't think so," said Peter Cardillo, director of research at Westfalia Investments. "I suspect we're in for a lower opening but the stronger dollar should support bonds and that will help."

One other glimmer of hope could come from Tuesday's book-to-bill index, which rose to 0.90 in August from a revised 0.86 in July. Though still fairly weak, the index's improvement during a seasonally slow month was a positive development for the troubled semiconductor sector.
Motorola specifically cited continued weakess in semiconductor unit demand and pricing in its profit warning.
At 1200 EDT/1600 GMT, the Federal Reserve will release its Beige Book economic survey. The report is expected to show hints of tighter labor markets but tame inflation numbers for finished goods.
In Tokyo, stocks moved a trace higher in lackluster trade. The Nikkei-225 Average rose 11 points to 20,571.
U.S. stocks were little changed in London, with markets on hold ahead of the Fed's Beige Book report. The FTSE-100 index fell 16.6 points to 3899.5.
The dollar was steady in Tokyo but pushed above the key 110 yen level in European trade, where it also eased against the German mark.
Bonds softened in early trade. The benchmark 30-year U.S. Treasury fell 11/32 to yield 7.14 percent.
The S&P 500 index future fell 2.05 points to 663.05.

Sam Zell, whose company Manufactured Home Communities Inc is trying to acquire Chateau Properties Inc, is arguing Chateau's top executives have a conflict of interest in deciding which of three bids to accept for the company, the New York Times Marketplace column reports.
Zell argues that the executives are more concerned with avoiding taxes than with getting the best offer, the column states.
The Wall Street Journal's Heard on the Street column reports that many money managers are focusing on seeking out the best acquirers in the ever-consolidating banking industry as investment choices.
